docs.lead_paragraph: Ritalin, Ritalin, seizure drugs, Ritalin. So goes the rhythm of noontime for Mary Jane Kemper, nurse at the Donald McKay School in East Boston, as she trots her tray of brown plastic vials and paper water cups from class to class, dispensing pills into outstretched young palms. In this ever-more-pharmacologized society, hers is a more common and demanding American school routine, as nurses, once known mainly as providers of Band-Aids, cots and hearing tests, find themselves increasingly in thrall to millions of midday doses, mainly for attention deficit disorder, but also for psychiatric and chronic illnesses.

headline.main: For School Nurses, More Than Tending the Sick

docs.abstract: School systems in Boston and elsewhere are engaged in debate over changing role of school nurses as students' needs have become more complex; nurses are struggling to juggle triage of sick-feeling students with growing load of other duties; many say jobs are changing because American life has changed; mention increased diagnoses of psychiatric illness and learning disabilities and more drugs to treat such disorders; point to policies of 'inclusion' that have populated public schools with scatterings of chronically ill children who would formerly have gone to special institutions; voice impression that behavioral problems right up to classroom violence have worsened, requiring more collaboration by nurses with school teams; express growing sense that school is, in part, health care provider, leaned on heavily by working parents; debate over their role in Boston school system discussed; photo (M)
